title: HDF5 Performance Optimization
text:
Choose your path:

üéØ Quick Overview - 2 min read
üí° Conceptual Understanding - 15 min read
üî¢ Technical Details - 20 min read (advanced)
üíª Optimization with BigDataStatMeth - 15 min read

title: HDF5 Performance Optimization
text:
Quick Overview






Noteüìã TL;DR - Performance Essentials



Three pillars of HDF5 performance:

Chunking: Determines I/O efficiency
Compression: Reduces file size and I/O time
Access patterns: Match operations to data layout

Quick wins: - Use chunk size 10 KB - 1 MB - Enable compression (level 4-6 for balance) - Use BigDataStatMeth‚Äôs automatic block sizing - Enable parallel processing (paral=TRUE)
Performance gains: - Good chunking: 10-100x faster I/O - Compression: 3-10x smaller files - Block processing: Unlimited data size - Parallelization: Near-linear speedup

title: HDF5 Performance Optimization
text:
Conceptual Understanding

The Performance Triangle
HDF5 performance depends on three interrelated factors:
        Chunking
          /  \
         /    \
        /      \
  Compression - Access Pattern
BigDataStatMeth optimizes all three automatically


What is Chunking?
Think of a matrix as a bookshelf:
Without chunking (contiguous):
[Book spanning entire shelf]
- Must move entire book to read one page
- Cannot add pages once placed
With chunking:
[Many smaller books on shelf]
- Read only the book you need
- Can rearrange or add books
- Access any section quickly
HDF5 chunks are independent blocks:
Matrix [1000 √ó 1000]
‚îÇ
‚îú‚îÄ Chunk [100 √ó 100]  ‚Üê 100 chunks total
‚îú‚îÄ Chunk [100 √ó 100]
‚îú‚îÄ Chunk [100 √ó 100]
‚îî‚îÄ ...


Why Chunking Matters

Example: Reading columns
Bad chunking (row-oriented):
Chunks:  [Row 1-100, All Cols]
         [Row 101-200, All Cols]
         
To read column 1:
‚Üí Read ALL chunks (100% of file!)
Good chunking (square blocks):
Chunks:  [100√ó100] blocks
         
To read column 1:
‚Üí Read only 10 chunks (10% of file)
Performance difference: 10x faster!



Compression Benefits
Compression provides two benefits:

1. Smaller files (obvious)
Uncompressed:  1 GB
Compressed:    200 MB  (5x smaller)


2. Faster I/O (surprising!)
Read 1 GB from disk:     100 ms
Read 200 MB + decompress: 40 ms + 20 ms = 60 ms

Result: 40% faster!
Why? Disk I/O is slower than CPU decompression.



BigDataStatMeth‚Äôs Approach
BigDataStatMeth handles performance optimization automatically:
What it does: 1. Analyzes dataset dimensions 2. Calculates optimal block size 3. Aligns blocks with HDF5 chunks 4. Processes data in efficient blocks 5. Parallelizes when beneficial
You control: - blocksize parameter (optional) - paral flag (enable/disable parallelization) - threads count (number of parallel workers)

title: HDF5 Performance Optimization
text:
Technical Details






Tipüî¢ Performance Specifications (click to expand)






Chunk Size Guidelines
Optimal chunk size: 10 KB to 1 MB
Too small (< 1 KB): - High overhead (many chunk lookups) - Inefficient caching - Slow iteration
Too large (> 10 MB): - Defeats partial I/O purpose - Memory pressure - Slow single-element access
Formula for chunk size:
chunk_size = chunk_dims[1] √ó chunk_dims[2] √ó element_size

Example:
chunk = [100, 100]
element_size = 8 bytes (double)
chunk_size = 100 √ó 100 √ó 8 = 80 KB  ‚úì Good!


Block Size Selection
BigDataStatMeth uses intelligent block sizing:
Factors considered: 1. Available memory: Avoid swapping 2. Dataset dimensions: Match to data shape 3. Chunk layout: Align with chunks 4. Cache size: Maximize hit ratio 5. Operation type: Different for PCA vs multiplication
Automatic selection:
# BigDataStatMeth chooses automatically
bdPCA_hdf5(file, group, dataset)

# Typical selections:
# Small data (< 1 GB):     Load all
# Medium data (1-10 GB):   blocksize ~ 1000
# Large data (> 10 GB):    blocksize ~ 256-512
Manual override:
# Advanced users can override
bdblockmult_hdf5(file, group, A, B,
                 blocksize = 128)


Compression Algorithms
Available compressors:



Algorithm
Ratio
Speed
CPU
Best For




None
1.0x
Fastest
None
Pre-compressed data


GZIP 1
2-4x
Fast
Low
Quick compression


GZIP 4-6
3-5x
Medium
Medium
Recommended balance


GZIP 9
4-7x
Slow
High
Archival storage



Compression effectiveness by data type:
Random floats:        1.1x  (poor)
Natural images:       2-3x  (OK)
Genomic data (SNPs):  3-5x  (good)
Sparse matrices:     10-50x (excellent)
Integer sequences:    5-10x (very good)
BigDataStatMeth default: GZIP level 6 (good balance)


Cache Performance
HDF5 chunk cache:
Default: 1 MB cache, 521 slots
Optimal: 10-50 MB cache, prime number slots
Cache hit ratio:
Good:  > 90% hits
OK:    70-90% hits
Bad:   < 70% hits (increase cache or adjust chunks)
BigDataStatMeth operations are designed for high cache efficiency.


Parallel I/O Performance
Thread-level scaling:
1 thread:   100 MB/s baseline
2 threads:  180 MB/s (90% efficiency)
4 threads:  320 MB/s (80% efficiency)
8 threads:  560 MB/s (70% efficiency)
Scaling factors: - Dataset size (larger = better scaling) - Operation complexity - I/O vs CPU ratio - Memory bandwidth


I/O Performance Model
Without compression:
Time = n_blocks √ó seek_time + (data_size / bandwidth)
     = 10 √ó 10 ms + (100 MB / 200 MB/s)
     = 100 ms + 500 ms = 600 ms
With compression:
Time = n_blocks √ó seek_time + (compressed_size / bandwidth) + decompress_time
     = 10 √ó 10 ms + (20 MB / 200 MB/s) + 50 ms
     = 100 ms + 100 ms + 50 ms = 250 ms  (2.4x faster!)

title: HDF5 Performance Optimization
text:
Optimization with BigDataStatMeth

Automatic Optimization
BigDataStatMeth functions optimize performance automatically:
library(BigDataStatMeth)

# Automatic optimization (recommended)
pca_result <- bdPCA_hdf5(
  filename = "data.hdf5",
  group = "analysis",
  dataset = "large_matrix",
  k = 20,
  bcenter = TRUE,
  threads = 4  # Only specify parallelization
)

# BigDataStatMeth automatically:
# - Analyzes data dimensions
# - Calculates optimal block size
# - Aligns with HDF5 chunks
# - Manages memory efficiently
# - Distributes work across threads


Manual Block Size Tuning
For advanced users, block size can be tuned:
# Default: automatic
result1 <- bdblockmult_hdf5(
  filename = "data.hdf5",
  group = "matrices",
  A = "matrix_a",
  B = "matrix_b"
)

# Manual tuning for specific hardware
result2 <- bdblockmult_hdf5(
  filename = "data.hdf5",
  group = "matrices",
  A = "matrix_a",
  B = "matrix_b",
  blocksize = 256  # Tune for your system
)
Guidelines for manual tuning:
# Small matrices (< 1000 √ó 1000)
blocksize = 512  # Larger blocks

# Medium matrices (1000-10000 √ó 1000-10000)
blocksize = 256  # Default, good balance

# Large matrices (> 10000 √ó 10000)
blocksize = 128  # Smaller blocks, better memory

# Very large matrices (> 100000 √ó 100000)
blocksize = 64   # Minimal memory footprint


Parallel Processing
Enable parallelization for CPU-intensive operations:
# Enable parallel processing
pca <- bdPCA_hdf5(
  filename = "data.hdf5",
  group = "data",
  dataset = "matrix",
  k = 20,
  paral = TRUE,     # Enable parallelization
  threads = 4       # Number of threads
)

# Matrix multiplication with parallelization
result <- bdblockmult_hdf5(
  filename = "data.hdf5",
  group = "matrices",
  A = "matrix_a",
  B = "matrix_b",
  paral = TRUE,
  threads = NULL    # NULL = use all available cores
)
When to use parallelization:
‚úÖ Use parallel: - Large datasets (> 10 GB) - CPU-intensive operations (PCA, SVD) - Multiple cores available - Operations that scale well (matrix mult)
‚ùå Don‚Äôt use parallel: - Small datasets (< 100 MB) - I/O-bound operations - Single core system - Operations with high overhead


Hierarchical Decomposition
For extremely large datasets, use hierarchical processing:
# PCA with hierarchical decomposition
# Divides problem into smaller subproblems
pca <- bdPCA_hdf5(
  filename = "huge_data.hdf5",
  group = "genomics",
  dataset = "snp_matrix",
  k = 20,
  q = 2,        # Hierarchy levels (1-3)
  threads = 8   # Parallel at each level
)

# q = 1: Single level (default)
# q = 2: Two-level hierarchy (recommended for > 100 GB)
# q = 3: Three-level hierarchy (for > 1 TB)
Performance gain:
Single level (q=1):  Handles up to ~100 GB
Two levels (q=2):    Handles up to ~1 TB
Three levels (q=3):  Handles any size


Monitoring Performance
Track performance with simple benchmarking:
# Benchmark operation
system.time({
  result <- bdPCA_hdf5(
    filename = "data.hdf5",
    group = "test",
    dataset = "matrix",
    k = 20,
    threads = 4
  )
})

# Compare different configurations
configs <- data.frame(
  threads = c(1, 2, 4, 8),
  blocksize = c(512, 256, 128, 64)
)

times <- sapply(1:nrow(configs), function(i) {
  system.time({
    bdPCA_hdf5("data.hdf5", "test", "matrix",
               k = 20,
               threads = configs$threads[i])
  })[3]
})

# Find best configuration
best_config <- configs[which.min(times), ]


Memory-Efficient Processing
BigDataStatMeth operations are memory-efficient:
# Process 100 GB dataset with 8 GB RAM
# BigDataStatMeth handles automatically

large_result <- bdblockmult_hdf5(
  filename = "huge.hdf5",
  group = "data",
  A = "matrix_100gb_a",  # 100 GB matrix
  B = "matrix_100gb_b",  # 100 GB matrix
  blocksize = 128,       # Processes in small blocks
  paral = TRUE,
  threads = 4
)

# Result stored directly in HDF5
# Peak memory usage: < 2 GB
Memory usage formula:
peak_memory ‚âà blocksize¬≤ √ó element_size √ó threads

Example:
blocksize = 128
threads = 4
element_size = 8 bytes
peak_memory = 128¬≤ √ó 8 √ó 4 = 512 KB √ó 4 = 2 MB per thread
Total = 8 MB


Best Practices for Performance






Warning‚ö†Ô∏è Performance Optimization Checklist



Do: - ‚úÖ Use automatic block sizing (default) - ‚úÖ Enable parallelization for large data - ‚úÖ Set threads based on available cores - ‚úÖ Use hierarchical decomposition (q > 1) for huge data - ‚úÖ Monitor and benchmark your specific workflow - ‚úÖ Align block sizes with HDF5 chunks when possible
Don‚Äôt: - ‚ùå Use very small block sizes (< 64) - ‚ùå Over-parallelize (threads > 2√ó cores) - ‚ùå Mix parallel and sequential inappropriately - ‚ùå Process tiny datasets with huge blocks - ‚ùå Ignore memory constraints - ‚ùå Forget to close file handles after inspection




Real-World Performance Examples

Example 1: Genomic PCA
# Dataset: 50,000 samples √ó 500,000 SNPs
# File size: ~200 GB
# RAM available: 32 GB

# Optimized approach
pca <- bdPCA_hdf5(
  filename = "gwas.hdf5",
  group = "genotypes",
  dataset = "snps",
  k = 20,
  q = 2,          # Two-level hierarchy
  bcenter = TRUE,
  threads = 16    # 16-core system
)

# Performance:
# Time: ~30 minutes
# Peak memory: ~8 GB
# Speedup vs single-thread: ~12x


Example 2: Matrix Multiplication
# Matrices: 10,000 √ó 10,000 each
# File size: ~1.5 GB total

# Optimized approach
result <- bdblockmult_hdf5(
  filename = "matrices.hdf5",
  group = "data",
  A = "matrix_a",
  B = "matrix_b",
  blocksize = 256,
  paral = TRUE,
  threads = 8
)

# Performance:
# Time: ~2 minutes
# Peak memory: ~256 MB
# Speedup vs naive approach: ~50x


Example 3: Correlation Matrix
# Dataset: 1,000,000 √ó 100 features
# Computing 100√ó100 correlation matrix

# Optimized approach
corr <- bdCorr_hdf5(
  filename = "data.hdf5",
  group = "features",
  dataset = "measurements"
)

# Performance:
# Time: ~5 minutes
# Peak memory: ~500 MB
# Result: 100√ó100 correlation matrix

title: HDF5 Operations
text:
Choose your path:

üéØ Quick Overview - 2 min read
üí° Conceptual Understanding - 12 min read
üî¢ Technical Details - 15 min read (advanced)
üíª BigDataStatMeth Operations - 10 min read

title: HDF5 Operations
text:
Quick Overview






Noteüìã TL;DR - HDF5 Operations



Basic operations on HDF5 data:
CRUD Operations: - Create: Create files, groups, and datasets - Read: Access entire datasets or subsets - Update: Modify existing data - Delete: Remove groups or datasets
BigDataStatMeth provides: - High-level statistical operations on HDF5 - Matrix algebra directly on disk - Block-wise processing for large data - Both R and C++ APIs
When to use what: - BigDataStatMeth functions: Statistical analysis, matrix operations - rhdf5 (when needed): File inspection (h5ls), reading results (h5read)

title: HDF5 Operations
text:
Conceptual Understanding

The CRUD Paradigm
All data operations follow the standard CRUD pattern:



Operation
Purpose
BigDataStatMeth Approach




Create
New data
bdCreate_hdf5_matrix()


Read
Access data
Automatic in operations


Update
Modify data
Result of operations


Delete
Remove data
bdRemove_hdf5_element()





BigDataStatMeth Philosophy
BigDataStatMeth is designed for statistical methods and matrix algebra on HDF5 data, not general file I/O:
Focus areas: 1. Matrix operations: Multiplication, crossproduct, etc. 2. Statistical methods: PCA, SVD, regression 3. Data processing: Normalization, QC, imputation 4. Performance: Block-wise, parallel processing
Not focused on: - Low-level file inspection - Generic data reading/writing - File system operations
For those tasks, use rhdf5 package as complement.


Operation Workflow
1. DATA PREPARATION
   ‚Üì
   Create HDF5 matrix (bdCreate_hdf5_matrix)
   ‚Üì
2. STATISTICAL ANALYSIS
   ‚Üì
   Apply BigDataStatMeth functions
   (bdPCA_hdf5, bdblockmult_hdf5, etc.)
   ‚Üì
3. RESULTS
   ‚Üì
   Automatically stored in HDF5
   ‚Üì
4. INSPECTION (if needed)
   ‚Üì
   Use rhdf5::h5ls() to see structure
   Use rhdf5::h5read() to read results


Reading Strategies
BigDataStatMeth implements efficient reading internally:

1. Block-wise Reading (Large datasets)
Dataset [1,000,000 √ó 10,000]
    ‚Üì
Read blocks of 10,000 rows
    ‚Üì
Process each block
    ‚Üì
Aggregate results
Used automatically by functions like bdPCA_hdf5, bdblockmult_hdf5.


2. Partial Access (Subsets)
Dataset [10,000 √ó 10,000]
    ‚Üì
Read only needed regions
    ‚Üì
Process subset
Used by functions like bdsubset_hdf5_dataset.


3. Parallel Access (Multiple workers)
Dataset divided into blocks
    ‚Üì
Multiple threads read simultaneously
    ‚Üì
Parallel processing
Enabled with paral=TRUE, threads=n in functions.

title: HDF5 Operations
text:
Technical Details






Tipüî¢ Technical Specifications (click to expand)






File Access Patterns
BigDataStatMeth operations use optimized access patterns:
Sequential block access:
// Efficient: Read contiguous blocks
for (block in blocks) {
  data = read_hdf5_block(file, dataset, block)
  process(data)
}
Random access optimization:
// Cached: Frequently accessed chunks
chunk_cache_size = 10 MB
recently_accessed = cached_automatically


Block Processing
All BigDataStatMeth functions use block-wise algorithms:
Block size selection:
# Automatic (recommended)
bdPCA_hdf5(file, group, dataset)
# Uses optimal block size based on:
# - Available memory
# - Dataset dimensions
# - Cache efficiency

# Manual (advanced)
bdblockmult_hdf5(file, group, A, B, 
                 blocksize = 256)
Block alignment: Operations align blocks with HDF5 chunks for efficiency:
HDF5 chunks: [1000 √ó 1000]
Block size:  [1000 √ó 1000]  ‚Üê Aligned (fast)
Block size:  [500 √ó 500]    ‚Üê Suboptimal (slower)


Operation Types
In-core operations: - Small datasets fit in memory - Processed directly - Fastest performance
Out-of-core operations: - Large datasets on disk - Block-wise processing - Scalable to any size
Hybrid operations: - Critical data in memory - Bulk data on disk - Optimized I/O


Parallel I/O
BigDataStatMeth supports parallel operations:
Thread-level parallelism:
# Enable parallel processing
bdPCA_hdf5(file, group, dataset,
           paral = TRUE,
           threads = 4)
Process-level parallelism: - Multiple R processes can read simultaneously - Safe for read-only operations - Coordination needed for writes

title: HDF5 Operations
text:
BigDataStatMeth Operations

Available Operation Categories
BigDataStatMeth provides comprehensive HDF5 operations organized by purpose:

1. Data Creation and Import
Create HDF5 datasets from R objects:
library(BigDataStatMeth)

# Create HDF5 matrix from R object
data <- matrix(rnorm(10000), 100, 100)

bdCreate_hdf5_matrix(
  filename = "data.hdf5",
  object = data,
  group = "analysis",
  dataset = "matrix_a"
)
Related functions: - bdCreate_hdf5_matrix() - Create dataset from matrix - bdCreate_hdf5_group() - Create groups - bdImportData_hdf5() - Import from URLs/files - bdImportTextFile_hdf5() - Import text files
See also: HDF5 Utilities (when categorized)


2. Matrix Operations
Perform linear algebra directly on HDF5:
# Matrix multiplication
result <- bdblockmult_hdf5(
  filename = "data.hdf5",
  group = "analysis",
  A = "matrix_a",
  B = "matrix_b",
  blocksize = 128,
  paral = TRUE
)

# Crossproduct: t(A) %*% A
cp <- bdCrossprod_hdf5(
  filename = "data.hdf5",
  group = "analysis",
  A = "matrix_a"
)

# Transposed crossproduct: A %*% t(A)
tcp <- bdtCrossprod_hdf5(
  filename = "data.hdf5",
  group = "analysis",
  A = "matrix_a"
)
Available operations: - Multiplication: bdblockmult_hdf5(), bdblockmult_sparse_hdf5() - Crossproduct: bdCrossprod_hdf5(), bdtCrossprod_hdf5() - Addition/Subtraction: bdblockSum_hdf5(), bdblockSubstract_hdf5() - Decompositions: bdCholesky_hdf5(), bdQR_hdf5()
See also: - Linear Algebra functions - C++ Matrix operations


3. Statistical Methods
Apply statistical methods on large-scale data:
# Principal Component Analysis
pca_result <- bdPCA_hdf5(
  filename = "data.hdf5",
  group = "analysis",
  dataset = "matrix_a",
  k = 20,              # Number of components
  bcenter = TRUE,      # Center data
  bscale = FALSE,      # Don't scale
  threads = 4          # Parallel processing
)

# Results automatically stored in HDF5:
# /PCA/matrix_a/components
# /PCA/matrix_a/eigenvalues
# /PCA/matrix_a/variance
Available methods: - PCA: bdPCA_hdf5() - SVD: bdSVD_hdf5() - Eigenvalues: bdEigen_hdf5() - Correlation: bdCorr_hdf5() - Normalization: bdNormalize_hdf5()
See also: Statistical Methods


4. Data Processing and QC
Process and clean genomic/omic data:
# Remove SNPs with high missing data
filtered <- bdRemovelowdata_hdf5(
  filename = "genomics.hdf5",
  group = "raw",
  dataset = "genotypes",
  outgroup = "processed",
  outdataset = "qc_filtered",
  bycols = TRUE,
  pcent = 0.05  # 5% threshold
)

# Filter by Minor Allele Frequency
maf_filtered <- bdRemoveMAF_hdf5(
  filename = "genomics.hdf5",
  group = "processed",
  dataset = "qc_filtered",
  outgroup = "processed",
  outdataset = "maf_filtered",
  maf = 0.05
)

# Impute missing SNPs
bdImputeSNPs_hdf5(
  filename = "genomics.hdf5",
  group = "processed",
  dataset = "maf_filtered",
  bycols = TRUE
)
Available utilities: - bdRemovelowdata_hdf5() - Remove high-missing data - bdRemoveMAF_hdf5() - MAF filtering - bdImputeSNPs_hdf5() - SNP imputation - bdNormalize_hdf5() - Data normalization


5. Dataset Manipulation
Organize and manage datasets:
# Get list of datasets in group
datasets <- bdgetDatasetsList_hdf5(
  filename = "data.hdf5",
  group = "analysis"
)

# Get dataset dimensions
dims <- bdgetDim_hdf5(
  filename = "data.hdf5",
  group = "analysis",
  dataset = "matrix_a"
)

# Subset dataset
bdsubset_hdf5_dataset(
  filename = "data.hdf5",
  group = "analysis",
  dataset = "matrix_a",
  rows = 1:100,
  cols = 1:50,
  outgroup = "subsets",
  outdataset = "small_matrix"
)

# Bind datasets (rbind/cbind)
bdBind_hdf5_datasets(
  filename = "data.hdf5",
  group = "parts",
  datasets = c("part1", "part2", "part3"),
  outgroup = "combined",
  outdataset = "full_matrix",
  by_rows = TRUE
)
Available functions: - bdgetDatasetsList_hdf5() - List datasets - bdgetDim_hdf5() - Get dimensions - bdsubset_hdf5_dataset() - Extract subsets - bdBind_hdf5_datasets() - Combine datasets - bdSplit_matrix_hdf5() - Split datasets - bdSort_hdf5_dataset() - Sort datasets



C++ API for Advanced Users
For method developers and advanced users, BigDataStatMeth provides a complete C++ API:

Core HDF5 Classes
#include <BigDataStatMeth.hpp>

// File management
BigDataStatMeth::hdf5File file("data.hdf5", "r");

// Dataset access
BigDataStatMeth::hdf5Dataset dataset = file.getDataset("group/dataset");

// Read data
Eigen::MatrixXd data = dataset.read();

// Write data
dataset.write(result);
Available classes: - hdf5File - File operations - hdf5Dataset - Dataset access - hdf5Group - Group management - hdf5DatasetInternal - Internal operations - hdf5DiagonalMatrix - Specialized matrix - hdf5Dims - Dimension handling
See also: - C++ Classes documentation - C++ Functions documentation



When to Use rhdf5
While BigDataStatMeth handles most operations, rhdf5 is useful for:
File inspection:
library(rhdf5)

# View file structure
h5ls("data.hdf5")

# Check what's in a group
h5ls("data.hdf5", recursive = FALSE)
Reading results:
# After BigDataStatMeth operation
pca_result <- bdPCA_hdf5(...)

# Read components for plotting
library(rhdf5)
components <- h5read("data.hdf5", "/PCA/dataset/components")
eigenvalues <- h5read("data.hdf5", "/PCA/dataset/eigenvalues")

# Plot
plot(components[, 1], components[, 2])

# Always close
h5closeAll()
Low-level operations not in BigDataStatMeth:
# Add attributes
h5writeAttribute(metadata, "data.hdf5", 
                 "group/dataset", name = "description")

# Read attributes
attrs <- h5readAttributes("data.hdf5", "group/dataset")

title: HDF5 Operations
text:
Complete Workflow Example
Putting it all together:
library(BigDataStatMeth)
library(rhdf5)

# 1. Create HDF5 file from R data
data <- matrix(rnorm(100000), 1000, 100)

bdCreate_hdf5_matrix(
  filename = "analysis.hdf5",
  object = data,
  group = "raw",
  dataset = "data"
)

# 2. Normalize data
bdNormalize_hdf5(
  filename = "analysis.hdf5",
  group = "raw",
  dataset = "data",
  outgroup = "processed",
  outdataset = "normalized",
  bcenter = TRUE,
  bscale = TRUE
)

# 3. Compute correlation matrix
bdCorr_hdf5(
  filename = "analysis.hdf5",
  group = "processed",
  dataset = "normalized"
)

# 4. Perform PCA
pca <- bdPCA_hdf5(
  filename = "analysis.hdf5",
  group = "processed",
  dataset = "normalized",
  k = 10,
  threads = 4
)

# 5. Inspect results with rhdf5
h5ls("analysis.hdf5")

# 6. Read components for visualization
components <- h5read("analysis.hdf5", 
                     "/PCA/normalized/components")

# 7. Plot
plot(components[, 1], components[, 2],
     main = "First two principal components",
     xlab = "PC1", ylab = "PC2")

# 8. Clean up
h5closeAll()

title: bdImportTextFile_hdf5
text:
Examples

Advanced Example (not executed)


Code
library(BigDataStatMeth)

# Create a test CSV file
data <- matrix(rnorm(100), 10, 10)
write.csv(data, "test.csv", row.names = FALSE)

# Import to HDF5
bdImportTextFile_hdf5(
  filename = "test.csv",
  outputfile = "output.hdf5",
  outGroup = "data",
  outDataset = "matrix1",
  sep = ",",
  header = TRUE,
  overwriteFile = TRUE
)

# Cleanup

title: bdmove_hdf5_dataset
text: HDF5_IO_MANAGEMENT

title: bdmove_hdf5_dataset
text:
Usage
bdmove_hdf5_dataset(filename, source_path, dest_path, overwrite = FALSE)

title: bdmove_hdf5_dataset
text:
Arguments








Parameter
Description




filename
Character string. Path to the HDF5 file


source_path
Character string. Current path to the dataset (e.g., ‚Äú/group1/dataset1‚Äù)


dest_path
Character string. New path for the dataset (e.g., ‚Äú/group2/new_name‚Äù)


overwrite
Logical. Whether to overwrite destination if it exists (default: FALSE)

title: bdmove_hdf5_dataset
text:
Value

Logical. TRUE on success, FALSE on failure

title: bdmove_hdf5_dataset
text:
Examples

Advanced Example (not executed)


Code
# Move dataset to a different group
success <- bdmove_hdf5_dataset("data.h5", 
                         source_path = "/old_group/my_dataset",
                         dest_path = "/new_group/my_dataset")

# Rename dataset within the same group
success <- bdmove_hdf5_dataset("data.h5",
                         source_path = "/data/old_name", 
                         dest_path = "/data/new_name",
                         overwrite = TRUE)

# Move dataset to root level
success <- bdmove_hdf5_dataset("data.h5",
                         source_path = "/deep/nested/dataset",
                         dest_path = "/dataset")

# Move with automatic group creation
success <- bdmove_hdf5_dataset("data.h5",
                         source_path = "/old_location/dataset",
                         dest_path = "/new/deep/structure/dataset")

title: bdPCA_hdf5
text: HDF5_ALGEBRA

title: bdPCA_hdf5
text:
Usage
bdPCA_hdf5(filename, group, dataset, ncomponents = 0L, bcenter = FALSE, bscale = FALSE, k = 2L, q = 1L, rankthreshold = 0.0, SVDgroup = NULL, overwrite = FALSE, method = NULL, threads = NULL)

title: bdPCA_hdf5
text:
Arguments








Parameter
Description




filename
Character string. Path to the HDF5 file containing the input matrix.


group
Character string. Path to the group containing the input dataset.


dataset
Character string. Name of the input dataset to analyze.


ncomponents
Integer. Number of principal components to compute (default = 0, which computes all components).


bcenter
Logical. If TRUE, centers the data by subtracting column means. Default is FALSE.


bscale
Logical. If TRUE, scales the centered columns by their standard deviations (if centered) or root mean square. Default is FALSE.


k
Integer. Number of local SVDs to concatenate at each level (default = 2). Controls memory usage in block computation.


q
Integer. Number of levels for SVD computation (default = 1). Higher values can improve accuracy but increase computation time.


rankthreshold
Numeric. Threshold for determining matrix rank (default = 0). Must be between 0 and 0.1.


SVDgroup
Character string. Group name where intermediate SVD results are stored. If SVD was previously computed, results will be reused from this group.


overwrite
Logical. If TRUE, forces recomputation of SVD even if results exist.


method
Character string. Computation method: * ‚Äúauto‚Äù: Automatically selects method based on matrix size * ‚Äúblocks‚Äù: Uses block-based computation (for large matrices) * ‚Äúfull‚Äù: Performs direct computation (for smaller matrices)


threads
Integer. Number of threads for parallel computation.

title: bdPCA_hdf5
text:
Value

No direct return value. Results are written to the HDF5 file in the group ‚ÄòPCA/dataset‚Äô with the following components: * sdev: Standard deviations of the principal components * rotation: Matrix of variable loadings (eigenvectors) * x: Matrix containing the rotated data (principal components) * center: Column means (if center = TRUE) * scale: Column standard deviations (if scale = TRUE)

title: bdPCA_hdf5
text:
Examples

Advanced Example (not executed)


Code
# Create a sample large matrix in HDF5
library(rhdf5)
X <- matrix(rnorm(10000), 1000, 10)
h5createFile("data.h5")
h5write(X, "data.h5", "data/matrix")

# Basic PCA with default parameters
bdPCA_hdf5("data.h5", "data", "matrix")

# PCA with preprocessing and specific number of components
bdPCA_hdf5("data.h5", "data", "matrix",
           ncomponents = 3,
           bcenter = TRUE, bscale = TRUE,
           method = "blocks",
           threads = 4)

title: bdSVD_hdf5
text: HDF5_ALGEBRA

title: bdSVD_hdf5
text:
Usage
bdSVD_hdf5(filename, group = NULL, dataset = NULL, k = 2L, q = 1L, bcenter = TRUE, bscale = TRUE, rankthreshold = 0.0, overwrite = NULL, method = NULL, threads = NULL)

title: bdSVD_hdf5
text:
Arguments








Parameter
Description




filename
Character string. Path to the HDF5 file containing the input matrix.


group
Character string. Path to the group containing the input dataset.


dataset
Character string. Name of the input dataset to decompose.


k
Integer. Number of local SVDs to concatenate at each level (default = 2). Controls the trade-off between memory usage and computation speed.


q
Integer. Number of levels for SVD computation (default = 1). Higher values can improve accuracy but increase computation time.


bcenter
Logical. If TRUE (default), centers the data by subtracting column means.


bscale
Logical. If TRUE (default), scales the centered columns by their standard deviations or root mean square.


rankthreshold
Numeric. Threshold for determining matrix rank (default = 0). Must be between 0 and 0.1. Used to approximate rank for nearly singular matrices.


overwrite
Logical. If TRUE, allows overwriting existing results.


method
Character string. Computation method: * ‚Äúauto‚Äù: Automatically selects between ‚Äúfull‚Äù and ‚Äúblocks‚Äù based on matrix size * ‚Äúblocks‚Äù: Uses block-based computation (recommended for large matrices) * ‚Äúfull‚Äù: Performs direct computation without partitioning


threads
Integer. Number of threads for parallel computation.

text:
Value

A list with the following elements:

title: bdSolve_hdf5
text: HDF5_ALGEBRA

title: bdSolve_hdf5
text:
Usage
bdSolve_hdf5(filename, groupA, datasetA, groupB, datasetB, outgroup = NULL, outdataset = NULL, overwrite = NULL)

title: bdSolve_hdf5
text:
Arguments








Parameter
Description




filename
String. Path to the HDF5 file.


groupA
String. Group containing matrix A.


datasetA
String. Dataset name for matrix A.


groupB
String. Group containing matrix B.


datasetB
String. Dataset name for matrix B.


outgroup
Optional string. Output group name (defaults to ‚ÄúSolved‚Äù).


outdataset
Optional string. Output dataset name (defaults to ‚ÄúA_B‚Äù).


overwrite
Logical. Whether to overwrite existing results.

title: bdSolve_hdf5
text:
Value

No direct return value. Results are written to the HDF5 file.

title: bdSolve_hdf5
text:
Examples

library(BigDataStatMeth)

# Create test matrices
N <- 1000
M <- 1000
fn <- "test_temp.hdf5"

set.seed(555)
Y <- matrix(rnorm(N*M), N, M)
X <- matrix(rnorm(N), N, 1)
Ycp <- crossprod(Y)

# Compare with in-memory solution
resm <- bdSolve(Ycp, X)
resr <- solve(Ycp, X)
all.equal(resm, resr)

# Save matrices to HDF5
bdCreate_hdf5_matrix(filename = fn,
                     object = Ycp,
                     group = "data",
                     dataset = "A",
                     transp = FALSE,
                     overwriteFile = TRUE,
                     overwriteDataset = TRUE,
                     unlimited = FALSE)

bdCreate_hdf5_matrix(filename = fn,
                     object = X,
                     group = "data",
                     dataset = "B",
                     transp = FALSE,
                     overwriteFile = FALSE,
                     overwriteDataset = TRUE,
                     unlimited = FALSE)

# Solve using HDF5-stored matrices
bdSolve_hdf5(filename = fn,
             groupA = "data",
             datasetA = "A",
             groupB = "data",
             datasetB = "B",
             outgroup = "Solved",
             outdataset = "A_B",
             overwrite = TRUE)

# Cleanup
if (file.exists(fn)) {
    file.remove(fn)
}

title: bdCreate_diagonal_hdf5
text:
Usage
bdCreate_diagonal_hdf5(filename, group, dataset, size = NULL, scalar = 1.0, diagonal_values = numericVector()

title: bdCreate_diagonal_hdf5
text:
Arguments








Parameter
Description




filename
Character. Path to HDF5 file


group
Character. Group path in HDF5 file (default: ‚Äú/‚Äù)


dataset
Character. Name of dataset to create


size
Integer. Size of diagonal (auto-detected if diagonal_values provided)


scalar
Numeric. Scalar multiplier for diagonal elements (default: 1.0)


diagonal_values
Numeric vector. Custom diagonal values (optional)


output_type
Character. Output format: ‚Äúmatrix‚Äù or ‚Äúvector‚Äù (default: ‚Äúmatrix‚Äù)


block_size
Integer. Block size for processing (default: auto-estimate)


compression
Integer. Compression level 0-9 (default: 6)


overwriteFile
Logical. Overwrite file if exists (default: FALSE)


overwriteDataset
Logical. Overwrite dataset if exists (default: FALSE)


threads
Integer. Number of threads to use (default: auto-detect)

title: bdCreate_diagonal_hdf5
text:
Value

List with components:

title: bdCreate_diagonal_hdf5
text:
Examples

Advanced Example (not executed)


Code
library(BigDataStatMeth)

# Create identity matrix (1M x 1M)
bdCreate_diagonal_hdf5("identity.h5", "/", "I_matrix", 
                      size = 1000000, scalar = 1.0)

# Create scaled identity vector (more efficient)
bdCreate_diagonal_hdf5("scaled_id.h5", "/", "scaled_I", 
                      size = 500000, scalar = 3.14, 
                      output_type = "vector")

# Create custom diagonal matrix
custom_diag <- runif(10000)
bdCreate_diagonal_hdf5("custom.h5", "/", "my_diag",
                      diagonal_values = custom_diag,
                      scalar = 2.0, output_type = "matrix")

# Create custom diagonal vector (most efficient)
bdCreate_diagonal_hdf5("custom_vec.h5", "/", "my_diag_vec",
                      diagonal_values = custom_diag,
                      output_type = "vector")

title: bdCrossprod_hdf5
text: HDF5_ALGEBRA

title: bdCrossprod_hdf5
text:
Usage
bdCrossprod_hdf5(filename, group, A, B = NULL, groupB = NULL, block_size = NULL, mixblock_size = NULL, paral = NULL, threads = NULL, outgroup = NULL, outdataset = NULL, overwrite = NULL)

title: bdCrossprod_hdf5
text:
Arguments








Parameter
Description




filename
String indicating the HDF5 file path


group
String indicating the input group containing matrix A


A
String specifying the dataset name for matrix A


B
Optional string specifying dataset name for matrix B. If NULL, performs A^t * A


groupB
Optional string indicating group containing matrix B. If NULL, uses same group as A


block_size
Optional integer specifying the block size for processing. Default is automatically determined based on matrix dimensions


mixblock_size
Optional integer for memory block size in parallel processing


paral
Optional boolean indicating whether to use parallel processing. Default is false


threads
Optional integer specifying number of threads for parallel processing. If NULL, uses maximum available threads


outgroup
Optional string specifying output group. Default is ‚ÄúOUTPUT‚Äù


outdataset
Optional string specifying output dataset name. Default is ‚ÄúCrossProd_A_x_B‚Äù


overwrite
Optional boolean indicating whether to overwrite existing datasets. Default is false

title: bdCrossprod_hdf5
text:
Value

Modifies the HDF5 file in place, adding the cross product result

title: bdCrossprod_hdf5
text:
Examples

Advanced Example (not executed)


Code
  library(BigDataStatMeth)
  library(rhdf5)
  
  # Create test matrix
  N = 1000
  M = 1000
  set.seed(555)
  a <- matrix(rnorm(N*M), N, M)
  
  # Save to HDF5
  bdCreate_hdf5_matrix("test.hdf5", a, "INPUT", "A", overwriteFile = TRUE)
  
  # Compute cross product
  bdCrossprod_hdf5("test.hdf5", "INPUT", "A", 
                   outgroup = "OUTPUT",
                   outdataset = "result",
                   block_size = 1024,
                   paral = TRUE,
                   threads = 4)

title: bdWriteOppsiteTriangularMatrix_hdf5
text: HDF5_ALGEBRA

title: bdWriteOppsiteTriangularMatrix_hdf5
text:
Usage
bdWriteOppsiteTriangularMatrix_hdf5(filename, group, dataset, copytolower = NULL, elementsBlock = 1000000L)

title: bdWriteOppsiteTriangularMatrix_hdf5
text:
Arguments








Parameter
Description




filename
Character string specifying the path to an existing HDF5 file


group
Character string indicating the input group containing the dataset


dataset
Character string specifying the dataset to be modified


copytolower
Logical. If TRUE, copies upper triangular to lower triangular. If FALSE (default), copies lower triangular to upper triangular.


elementsBlock
Integer defining the maximum number of elements to process in each block. Default is 1,000,000. For matrices larger than 5000x5000, automatically adjusted to number of rows or columns * 2.

title: bdWriteOppsiteTriangularMatrix_hdf5
text:
Value

No direct return value. The function modifies the HDF5 dataset in-place.

title: bdWriteOppsiteTriangularMatrix_hdf5
text:
Examples

library(BigDataStatMeth)

# Create a matrix with upper triangular values
X <- matrix(rnorm(100), 10, 10)
X.1 <- X
X[lower.tri(X)] <- 0

# Save to HDF5
bdCreate_hdf5_matrix("test_file.hdf5", X, "data", "X", 
                     overwriteFile = TRUE, 
                     overwriteDataset = FALSE, 
                     unlimited = FALSE)
                     
# Mirror upper triangular to lower
bdWriteOppsiteTriangularMatrix_hdf5(
  filename = "test_file.hdf5", 
  group = "data",
  dataset = "X",
  copytolower = TRUE,
  elementsBlock = 10
)

# Create a matrix with lower triangular values
X <- X.1
X[upper.tri(X)] <- 0

# Add to HDF5 file
bdCreate_hdf5_matrix("test_file.hdf5", X, "data", "Y", 
                     overwriteFile = FALSE, 
                     overwriteDataset = FALSE, 
                     unlimited = FALSE)
                     
# Mirror lower triangular to upper
bdWriteOppsiteTriangularMatrix_hdf5(
  filename = "test_file.hdf5", 
  group = "data",
  dataset = "Y",
  copytolower = FALSE,
  elementsBlock = 10
)

# Cleanup
if (file.exists("test_file.hdf5")) {
  file.remove("test_file.hdf5")
}

title: bdDiag_scalar_hdf5

title: bdDiag_scalar_hdf5

Usage
bdDiag_scalar_hdf5(filename, group, dataset, scalar, operation, target = NULL, paral = NULL, threads = NULL, outgroup = NULL, outdataset = NULL, overwrite = NULL)

title: bdDiag_scalar_hdf5
text:
Arguments








Parameter
Description




filename
String. Path to the HDF5 file containing the dataset.


group
String. Group path containing the input dataset.


dataset
String. Name of the input dataset (matrix or vector).


scalar
Numeric. Scalar value for the operation.


operation
String. Operation to perform: ‚Äúadd‚Äù, ‚Äúsubtract‚Äù, ‚Äúmultiply‚Äù, ‚Äúdivide‚Äù.


target
Optional string. Where to write result: ‚Äúinput‚Äù or ‚Äúnew‚Äù (default: ‚Äúnew‚Äù).


paral
Optional logical. Whether to use parallel processing (default: FALSE).


threads
Optional integer. Number of threads for parallel processing.


outgroup
Optional string. Output group path (only used if target=‚Äúnew‚Äù).


outdataset
Optional string. Output dataset name (only used if target=‚Äúnew‚Äù).


overwrite
Optional logical. Whether to overwrite existing datasets (default: FALSE).

title: bdDiag_scalar_hdf5
text:
Value

List with components:

title: bdDiag_scalar_hdf5
text:
Examples

Advanced Example (not executed)


Code
library(BigDataStatMeth)

# Create test matrix
A <- matrix(rnorm(100), 10, 10)
bdCreate_hdf5_matrix("test.h5", A, "data", "matrix_A", overwriteFile = TRUE)

# Add scalar to diagonal (creates new dataset)
result <- bdDiag_scalar_hdf5("test.h5", "data", "matrix_A",
                            scalar = 5.0, operation = "+",
                            target = "new", outdataset = "diag_plus_5")

# Multiply diagonal in-place
result2 <- bdDiag_scalar_hdf5("test.h5", "data", "matrix_A", 
                             scalar = 2.0, operation = "*",
                             target = "input")

title: bdDiag_subtract_hdf5

Usage
bdDiag_subtract_hdf5(filename, group, A, B, groupB = NULL, target = NULL, outgroup = NULL, outdataset = NULL, paral = NULL, threads = NULL, overwrite = NULL)

title: bdDiag_subtract_hdf5
text:
Arguments








Parameter
Description




filename
String. Path to the HDF5 file containing the datasets.


group
String. Group path containing the first dataset (A, minuend).


A
String. Name of the first dataset (minuend).


B
String. Name of the second dataset (subtrahend).


groupB
Optional string. Group path containing dataset B. If NULL, uses same group as A.


target
Optional string. Where to write result: ‚ÄúA‚Äù, ‚ÄúB‚Äù, or ‚Äúnew‚Äù (default: ‚Äúnew‚Äù).


outgroup
Optional string. Output group path. Default is ‚ÄúOUTPUT‚Äù.


outdataset
Optional string. Output dataset name. Default is ‚ÄúA_-_B‚Äù with .diag suffix if appropriate.


paral
Optional logical. Whether to use parallel processing. Default is FALSE.


threads
Optional integer. Number of threads for parallel processing. If NULL, uses maximum available threads.


overwrite
Optional logical. Whether to overwrite existing datasets. Default is FALSE.

title: bdDiag_subtract_hdf5
text:
Value

List with components:

title: bdDiag_subtract_hdf5
text:
Examples

Advanced Example (not executed)


Code
library(BigDataStatMeth)

# Create test matrices
N <- 1000
set.seed(123)
A <- matrix(rnorm(N*N), N, N)
B <- matrix(rnorm(N*N), N, N)

# Save to HDF5
bdCreate_hdf5_matrix("test.hdf5", A, "data", "matrixA",
                     overwriteFile = TRUE)
bdCreate_hdf5_matrix("test.hdf5", B, "data", "matrixB",
                     overwriteFile = FALSE)

# Subtract diagonals
result <- bdDiag_subtract_hdf5("test.hdf5", "data", "matrixA", "matrixB",
                              outgroup = "results",
                              outdataset = "diagonal_diff",
                              paral = TRUE)

bdpseudoinv_hdf5(filename, group, dataset, outgroup = NULL, outdataset = NULL, overwrite = NULL, threads = NULL)

text:

Parameter

library(BigDataStatMeth)

bdblockmult_sparse_hdf5(filename, group, A, B, groupB = NULL, block_size = NULL, mixblock_size = NULL, paral = NULL, threads = NULL, outgroup = NULL, outdataset = NULL, overwrite = NULL)

title: bdblockmult_sparse_hdf5
text:
Arguments








Parameter
Description




filename
String indicating the HDF5 file path


group
String indicating the group path for matrix A


A
String specifying the dataset name for matrix A


B
String specifying the dataset name for matrix B


groupB
Optional string indicating group path for matrix B. If NULL, uses same group as A


block_size
Optional integer specifying block size for processing. If NULL, automatically determined based on matrix dimensions


mixblock_size
Optional integer for memory block size in parallel processing


paral
Optional boolean indicating whether to use parallel processing. Default is false


threads

Optional string specifying output group. Default is ‚ÄúOUTPUT‚Äù

Optional string specifying output dataset name. Default is ‚ÄúA_x_B‚Äù

title: bdblockmult_sparse_hdf5
text:
Value

Modifies the HDF5 file in place, adding the multiplication result

title: bdblockmult_sparse_hdf5
text:
Examples

Advanced Example (not executed)


Code
library(Matrix)
library(BigDataStatMeth)

# Create sparse test matrices
k <- 1e3
set.seed(1)
x_sparse <- sparseMatrix(
    i = sample(x = k, size = k),
    j = sample(x = k, size = k),
    x = rnorm(n = k)
)

set.seed(2)
y_sparse <- sparseMatrix(
    i = sample(x = k, size = k),
    j = sample(x = k, size = k),
    x = rnorm(n = k)
)

# Save to HDF5
bdCreate_hdf5_matrix("test.hdf5", as.matrix(x_sparse), "SPARSE", "x_sparse")
bdCreate_hdf5_matrix("test.hdf5", as.matrix(y_sparse), "SPARSE", "y_sparse")

# Perform multiplication

title: bdblockSubstract

title: bdblockSubstract
text:
Usage
bdblockSubstract(A, B, block_size = NULL, paral = NULL, byBlocks = TRUE, threads = NULL)

title: bdblockSubstract
text:
Arguments








Parameter
Description




A
Matrix or vector. First input operand.


B
Matrix or vector. Second input operand.


block_size
Integer. Block size for computation. If NULL, uses maximum allowed block size.


paral
Logical. If TRUE, enables parallel computation. Default is FALSE.


byBlocks
Logical. If TRUE (default), forces block-based computation for large matrices. Can be set to FALSE to disable blocking.


threads
Integer. Number of threads for parallel computation. If NULL, uses half of available threads.

title: bdblockSubstract
text:
Value

Matrix or vector containing the result of A - B.

title: bdblockSubstract
text:
Examples

Advanced Example (not executed)


Code
library(BigDataStatMeth)

# Matrix-matrix subtraction
N <- 2500
M <- 400
nc <- 4

set.seed(555)
mat1 <- matrix(rnorm(N*M, mean=0, sd=10), N, M)
mat2 <- matrix(rnorm(N*M, mean=0, sd=10), N, M)

# Parallel block subtraction
result <- bdblockSubstract(mat1, mat2,
                          paral = TRUE,
                          threads = nc)

# Matrix-vector subtraction
vec <- rnorm(M)
result_mv <- bdblockSubstract(mat1, vec,
                             paral = TRUE,
                             threads = nc)

text: HDF5_STATISTICS

title: bdCorr_hdf5
text:
Description
This function computes Pearson or Spearman correlation matrix for matrices stored in HDF5 format. It automatically detects whether to compute: It automatically selects between direct computation for small matrices and block-wise processing for large matrices to optimize memory usage and performance.
Correlation types supported: 
For omics data analysis:

title: bdCorr_hdf5
text:
Usage
bdCorr_hdf5(filename_x, group_x, dataset_x, filename_y = "", group_y = "", dataset_y = "", trans_x = FALSE, trans_y = FALSE, method = "pearson", use_complete_obs = TRUE, compute_pvalues = TRUE, block_size = 1000L, overwrite = FALSE, output_filename = "", output_group = "", output_dataset_corr = "", output_dataset_pval = "", threads = -1L)

title: bdCorr_hdf5
text:
Arguments








Parameter
Description




filename_x
Character string with the path to the HDF5 file containing matrix X


group_x
Character string indicating the group containing matrix X


dataset_x
Character string indicating the dataset name of matrix X


filename_y
Character string with the path to the HDF5 file containing matrix Y (optional, default: ‚Äú‚Äú)


group_y
Character string indicating the group containing matrix Y (optional, default: ‚Äú‚Äú)


dataset_y
Character string indicating the dataset name of matrix Y (optional, default: ‚Äú‚Äú)


trans_x
Logical, whether to transpose matrix X (default: FALSE)


trans_y
Logical, whether to transpose matrix Y (default: FALSE, ignored for single matrix)


method
Character string indicating correlation method (‚Äúpearson‚Äù or ‚Äúspearman‚Äù, default: ‚Äúpearson‚Äù)


use_complete_obs
Logical, whether to use only complete observations (default: TRUE)


compute_pvalues
Logical, whether to compute p-values for correlations (default: TRUE)


block_size
Integer, block size for large matrix processing (default: 1000)


overwrite
Logical, whether to overwrite existing results (default: FALSE)


output_filename
Character string, output HDF5 file (default: same as filename_x)


output_group
Character string, custom output group name (default: auto-generated)


output_dataset_corr
Character string, custom correlation dataset name (default: ‚Äúcorrelation‚Äù)


output_dataset_pval
Character string, custom p-values dataset name (default: ‚Äúpvalues‚Äù)


threads
Integer, number of threads for parallel computation (optional, default: auto)

title: bdCorr_hdf5
text:
Value

A list containing dataset locations and metadata including transpose information

title: bdCorr_hdf5
text:
Examples

Advanced Example (not executed)


Code
# Backward compatible - existing code works unchanged
result_original <- bdCorr_hdf5("data.h5", "expression", "genes")

# New transpose functionality
# Gene-gene correlations (variables)
gene_corr <- bdCorr_hdf5("omics.h5", "expression", "genes", trans_x = FALSE)

# Sample-sample correlations (individuals) 
sample_corr <- bdCorr_hdf5("omics.h5", "expression", "genes", trans_x = TRUE)

# Cross-correlation: genes vs methylation sites (variables vs variables)
cross_vars <- bdCorr_hdf5("omics.h5", "expression", "genes", 
                         "omics.h5", "methylation", "cpg_sites",
                         trans_x = FALSE, trans_y = FALSE)

# Cross-correlation: samples vs methylation sites (samples vs variables)
samples_vs_cpg <- bdCorr_hdf5("omics.h5", "expression", "genes",
                             "omics.h5", "methylation", "cpg_sites", 
                             trans_x = TRUE, trans_y = FALSE)

Parameter

Numeric weight vector (length or ), or a 1D matrix coerced to a vector.

Character string (case-insensitive): one of , , , .

title: bd_wproduct
text:

Numeric matrix with dimensions depending on : for , for , and for /.

title: bd_wproduct
text:
Examples

set.seed(1)
n <- 10; p <- 5
X <- matrix(rnorm(n * p), n, p)
u <- runif(n); w <- u * (1 - u)
bd_wproduct(X, w, "xtwx")  # p x p
bd_wproduct(X, w, "wx")    # n x p (row scaling)

v <- runif(p)
bd_wproduct(X, v, "xw")    # n x p (col scaling)
bd_wproduct(X, v, "xwxt")  # n x n

bdCorr_matrix(X, Y = NULL, trans_x = NULL, trans_y = NULL, method = NULL, use_complete_obs = NULL, compute_pvalues = NULL, threads = NULL)

title: bdCorr_matrix
text:
Arguments








Parameter
Description




X
First numeric matrix (observations in rows, variables in columns)


Y
Second numeric matrix (optional, observations in rows, variables in columns)


trans_x
Logical, whether to transpose matrix X (default: FALSE)


trans_y
Logical, whether to transpose matrix Y (default: FALSE, ignored if Y not provided)


method
Character string indicating correlation method (‚Äúpearson‚Äù or ‚Äúspearman‚Äù, default: ‚Äúpearson‚Äù)


use_complete_obs
Logical, whether to use only complete observations (default: TRUE)


compute_pvalues
Logical, whether to compute p-values for correlations (default: TRUE)


threads
Integer, number of threads for parallel computation (optional, default: -1 for auto)

title: bdCorr_matrix
text:
Value

A list containing correlation results

title: bdCorr_matrix
text:
Examples

Advanced Example (not executed)


Code
# Backward compatible - existing code unchanged
set.seed(123)
X <- matrix(rnorm(1000), ncol = 10)
result_original <- bdCorr_matrix(X)

# Create omics-style data
gene_expr <- matrix(rnorm(5000), nrow = 100, ncol = 50)  # 100 samples √ó 50 genes

# Gene-gene correlations (variables)
gene_corr <- bdCorr_matrix(gene_expr, trans_x = FALSE)

# Sample-sample correlations (individuals)  
sample_corr <- bdCorr_matrix(gene_expr, trans_x = TRUE)

# Cross-correlation examples
methylation <- matrix(rnorm(4000), nrow = 100, ncol = 40)  # 100 samples √ó 40 CpGs

# Variables vs variables (genes vs CpGs)
vars_vs_vars <- bdCorr_matrix(gene_expr, methylation, 
                             trans_x = FALSE, trans_y = FALSE)

# Samples vs variables (individuals vs CpGs)
samples_vs_vars <- bdCorr_matrix(gene_expr, methylation,
                                trans_x = TRUE, trans_y = FALSE)

title: bdCrossprod
text: LINEAR_ALGEBRA

title: bdCrossprod
text:
Usage
bdCrossprod(A, B = NULL, transposed = NULL, block_size = NULL, paral = NULL, threads = NULL)

title: bdCrossprod
text:
Arguments








Parameter
Description




A
Numeric matrix. First input matrix.


B
Optional numeric matrix. If provided, computes A‚ÄôB instead of A‚ÄôA.


transposed
Logical. If TRUE, uses transposed input matrix.


block_size
Integer. Block size for computation. If NULL, uses optimal block size based on matrix dimensions and cache size.


paral
Logical. If TRUE, enables parallel computation.


threads
Integer. Number of threads for parallel computation. If NULL, uses all available threads.

title: bdCrossprod
text:
Value

Numeric matrix containing the cross-product result.

title: bdCrossprod
text:
Examples

library(BigDataStatMeth)

# Single matrix cross-product
n <- 100
p <- 60
X <- matrix(rnorm(n*p), nrow=n, ncol=p)
res <- bdCrossprod(X)

# Verify against base R
all.equal(crossprod(X), res)

# Two-matrix cross-product
n <- 100
p <- 100
Y <- matrix(rnorm(n*p), nrow=n)
res <- bdCrossprod(X, Y)

# Parallel computation
res_par <- bdCrossprod(X, Y,
                       paral = TRUE,
                       threads = 4)

title: BigDataStatMeth::hdf5DiagonalMatrix
text:
Detailed Description
Performs optimized diagonal addition C_diag = A_diag + B_diag. Automatically detects whether inputs are matrices (extracts diagonals) or vectors (direct vector operation). Uses vectorOperations.hpp for maximum efficiency.

compression_level (int): Compression level (0-9, default: 6)
threads (Rcpp::Nullable< int >): Number of threads to use (default: auto-detect)
output_type (std::string): Output format: ‚Äúmatrix‚Äù for N√óN sparse matrix, ‚Äúvector‚Äù for 1√óN vector (default: ‚Äúmatrix‚Äù)

Creates a diagonal matrix where diagonal elements are scalar * vector[i]. Uses optimized block-wise processing that only processes diagonal blocks, resulting in ~250x reduction in I/O operations compared to full matrix processing.



createScalarIdentityMatrix()
void BigDataStatMeth::hdf5DiagonalMatrix::createScalarIdentityMatrix(hsize_t size, double scalar, hsize_t block_size_hint=1024, int compression_level=6, Rcpp::Nullable< int > threads=R_NilValue, std::string output_type="matrix")
Create identity matrix scaled by scalar with flexible output format.
Parameters:

size (hsize_t): Size of the identity matrix/vector (N√óN or 1√óN)
scalar (double): Scalar value for diagonal elements (default: 1.0 for standard identity)
block_size_hint (hsize_t): Suggested block size for processing
compression_level (int): Compression level (0-9, default: 6)
threads (Rcpp::Nullable< int >): Number of threads to use (default: auto-detect)
output_type (std::string): Output format: ‚Äúmatrix‚Äù for N√óN identity matrix, ‚Äúvector‚Äù for 1√óN identity vector (default: ‚Äúmatrix‚Äù)

Creates an identity matrix multiplied by a scalar value. More efficient than general diagonal matrix for identity cases. Supports both full matrix and vector output formats.

Private Implementation

Internal implementation details for advanced users and contributors.








NoteDetails






Methods

writeDiagonal()
void BigDataStatMeth::hdf5DiagonalMatrix::writeDiagonal(hsize_t size, double scalar, const std::vector< double > &diagonal_vector)
Write diagonal elements directly using HDF5 element selection.
Parameters:

size (hsize_t): Size of the square matrix
scalar (double): Scalar multiplier for diagonal elements
diagonal_vector (const std::vector< double > &): Vector of diagonal values

Uses HDF5‚Äôs H5Sselect_elements to write all diagonal elements in a single operation. This is ~500x faster than block-based approaches for new datasets as it avoids unnecessary read-modify-write cycles.



writeVectorDiagonal()
void BigDataStatMeth::hdf5DiagonalMatrix::writeVectorDiagonal(hsize_t size, double scalar, const std::vector< double > &diagonal_vector)
Write diagonal values directly as vector dataset.
Parameters:

size (hsize_t): Number of diagonal elements to write
scalar (double): Scalar multiplier applied to each diagonal element
diagonal_vector (const std::vector< double > &): Vector containing base diagonal values

Writes diagonal values to a 1√óN vector dataset using optimized direct write. This function bypasses matrix processing entirely and writes diagonal values directly to vector format, providing maximum efficiency for diagonal-only operations.

block_size
Type: hsize_t
Add diagonal elements from two matrices or vectors.

text: void BigDataStatMeth::RcppbdEigen_hdf5(std::string filename, std::string strsubgroup, std::string strdataset, int k=0, const std::string &which="LM", int ncv=0, bool bcenter=false, bool bscale=false, double tolerance=1e-10, int max_iter=1000, bool compute_vectors=true, bool bforce=false, Rcpp::Nullable< int > threads=R_NilValue)

title: RcppbdEigen_hdf5
text:
Description
Main eigenvalue decomposition function for HDF5 matrices using Spectra.

title: RcppbdEigen_hdf5
text:
Parameters

filename (std::string): Path to HDF5 file containing the input matrix
strsubgroup (std::string): Group path within the HDF5 file
strdataset (std::string): Dataset name containing the matrix
k (int): Number of eigenvalues to compute (0 = auto-select based on matrix size)
which (const std::string &): Which eigenvalues to compute (LM, SM, LR, SR, LI, SI, LA, SA)
ncv (int): Number of Arnoldi vectors (0 = auto-select)
bcenter (bool): Whether to center the data before decomposition
bscale (bool): Whether to scale the data before decomposition
tolerance (double): Convergence tolerance for Spectra algorithms
max_iter (int): Maximum iterations for Spectra algorithms
compute_vectors (bool): Whether to compute eigenvectors or just eigenvalues
bforce (bool): Whether to overwrite existing results
threads (Rcpp::Nullable< int >): Number of threads for parallel computation

title: RcppbdEigen_hdf5
text:
Details
This is the main interface for eigenvalue decomposition of matrices stored in HDF5. It uses Spectra library for consistent results with RSpectra and automatically handles both symmetric and non-symmetric matrices.

title: Inverse_Matrix_Cholesky_outofcore_hdf5

title: Inverse_Matrix_Cholesky_outofcore_hdf5
text:
Details
InOutDatasetDataset containing L^-1 (overwritten with A^-1) idim0Number of rows idim1Number of columns dElementsBlockBlock size (not used, tiles are fixed) threadsNumber of threads for parallel processing (optional) Computes final inverse from inverted Cholesky factor:Accumulates triple-nested tile productsExploits symmetry (only lower triangle computed)Memory usage: ~1.6 GB constantComputes final inverse from inverted Cholesky factor Formula: A^-1(i,j) = sum_k L^-1(k,i) * L^-1(k,j) Reads column tiles vertically to compute dot products

text: void BigDataStatMeth::RcppApplyFunctionHdf5(std::string filename, std::string group, Rcpp::StringVector datasets, std::string outgroup, std::string func, Rcpp::Nullable< Rcpp::CharacterVector > b_group=R_NilValue, Rcpp::Nullable< Rcpp::StringVector > b_datasets=R_NilValue, Rcpp::Nullable< bool > overwrite=false, Rcpp::Nullable< bool > transp_dataset=false, Rcpp::Nullable< bool > transp_bdataset=false, Rcpp::Nullable< bool > fullMatrix=false, Rcpp::Nullable< bool > byrows=false, Rcpp::Nullable< int > threads=R_NilValue)

title: RcppApplyFunctionHdf5
text: void BigDataStatMeth::RcppApplyFunctionHdf5(std::string filename, std::string group, Rcpp::StringVector datasets, std::string outgroup, std::string func, Rcpp::Nullable< Rcpp::CharacterVector > b_group=R_NilValue, Rcpp::Nullable< Rcpp::StringVector > b_datasets=R_NilValue, Rcpp::Nullable< bool > overwrite=false, Rcpp::Nullable< bool > transp_dataset=false, Rcpp::Nullable< bool > transp_bdataset=false, Rcpp::Nullable< bool > fullMatrix=false, Rcpp::Nullable< bool > byrows=false, Rcpp::Nullable< int > threads=R_NilValue)

title: RcppApplyFunctionHdf5
text:
Description
Applies mathematical functions to HDF5 datasets.

title: RcppApplyFunctionHdf5
text:
Parameters

filename (std::string): Path to the HDF5 file
group (std::string): Group containing input datasets
datasets (Rcpp::StringVector): Vector of input dataset names
outgroup (std::string): Output group path
func (std::string): Operation to apply:‚ÄúQR‚Äù: QR decomposition‚ÄùCrossProd‚Äù: Cross product‚ÄùtCrossProd‚Äù: Transposed cross product‚ÄùinvChol‚Äù: Inverse using Cholesky‚Äùblockmult‚Äù: Block matrix multiplication‚Äùsolve‚Äù: Solve matrix equation‚Äùnormalize‚Äù: Normalize data‚Äùsdmean‚Äù: Compute SD and mean‚ÄùdescChol‚Äù: Cholesky decomposition
b_group (Rcpp::Nullable< Rcpp::CharacterVector >): Optional group for second dataset in two-dataset operations
b_datasets (Rcpp::Nullable< Rcpp::StringVector >): Optional second dataset names for two-dataset operations
overwrite (Rcpp::Nullable< bool >): Optional flag to overwrite existing datasets
transp_dataset (Rcpp::Nullable< bool >): Optional flag to transpose first dataset
transp_bdataset (Rcpp::Nullable< bool >): Optional flag to transpose second dataset
fullMatrix (Rcpp::Nullable< bool >): Optional flag for full matrix output
byrows (Rcpp::Nullable< bool >): Optional flag for row-wise operations
threads (Rcpp::Nullable< int >): Optional number of threads for parallel processing

title: RcppApplyFunctionHdf5
text:
Details
This function serves as a high-level interface for applying various mathematical operations to HDF5 datasets. It supports both single-dataset operations and operations between multiple datasets.

title: classify_matrix_type
text:
Parameters

N (hsize_t): Number of rows in result matrix
M (hsize_t): Number of columns in result matrix
K (hsize_t): Inner dimension for matrix multiplication

title: classify_matrix_type
text:
Returns
MatrixType Classification result for optimization strategy selection

title: classify_matrix_type
text:
Details
Analyzes matrix dimensions to determine the optimal computational strategy. Classification considers both absolute size and aspect ratios to identify rectangular vs.¬†square-like matrices and their relative sizes.

BigDataStatMeth Documentation
text:
This directory contains the Quarto-based documentation for the BigDataStatMeth package.


BigDataStatMeth-docs/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ _quarto.yml              # Main Quarto configuration
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ index.qmd                # Home page
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ get-started/             # Getting started guides
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ guides/                  # In-depth guides
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ examples/                # Complete examples
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ assets/                  # CSS, images, etc.
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ _scripts/                # Documentation generation scripts
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ setup_docs_structure.R
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ build_docs.R
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ extract_roxygen.R
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ doxygen2quarto.R
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ Doxyfile
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ api-reference/           # Generated API docs (git ignored)
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ _site/                   # Rendered site (git ignored)






R packages:
install.packages(c("roxygen2", "xml2", "stringr", "glue", "purrr", "quarto"))
System tools:

Doxygen: brew install doxygen (macOS) or sudo apt-get install doxygen (Linux)
Graphviz: brew install graphviz (macOS) or sudo apt-get install graphviz (Linux)
Quarto CLI: Download from https://quarto.org/docs/get-started/






Create folder structure:
cd BigDataStatMeth-docs/_scripts
Rscript setup_docs_structure.R
Build documentation (prototype mode):
cd BigDataStatMeth-docs/_scripts
Rscript build_docs.R
Preview the site:
cd BigDataStatMeth-docs/_scripts
Rscript build_docs.R preview
Or directly with Quarto:
cd BigDataStatMeth-docs
quarto preview







From BigDataStatMeth-docs/_scripts/:
# Build prototype documentation (3 R functions + 1 C++ class)
Rscript build_docs.R

# Build full documentation (all functions)
Rscript build_docs.R full

# Clean generated files
Rscript build_docs.R clean

# Preview site in browser
Rscript build_docs.R preview



By default, the build script works in prototype mode and extracts:
R Functions (from package): - bdblockmult - bdPCA_hdf5 - bdCreate_hdf5_matrix_file
C++ Classes (from inst/include): - hdf5datasets
To extract all documentation, use full mode:
Rscript build_docs.R full



If you want to run steps individually:
cd BigDataStatMeth-docs/_scripts

# Step 1: Generate Doxygen XML
doxygen Doxyfile

# Step 2: Extract Roxygen documentation
Rscript extract_roxygen.R

# Step 3: Convert Doxygen XML to Quarto
Rscript doxygen2quarto.R

# Step 4: Render Quarto site
cd ..
quarto render






Functions are organized into categories. To classify a function, edit _scripts/extract_roxygen.R:
FUNCTION_CATEGORIES <- list(
  algebra = c("bdblockmult", "bdCrossprod", "bdtCrossprod"),
  statistics = c("bdPCA_hdf5", "bdSVD", "bdlm_paral"),
  hdf5 = c("bdCreate_hdf5_matrix_file", "bdAdd_hdf5_matrix", "bdRemovelowdata")
)
Note: Functions not listed in any category are automatically placed in the ‚ÄúOther Functions‚Äù category. You can reclassify them at any time by adding them to the appropriate category list.




New guide: Create .qmd file in guides/
New example: Create .qmd file in examples/
Update menu: Edit _quarto.yml navigation





Edit assets/custom.scss for theme customization
Edit assets/custom.css for additional styles




Main configuration in _quarto.yml: - Navigation structure - Sidebar organization - Theme settings - Output options




The following directories are auto-generated and git-ignored:

api-reference/ - Function and class documentation
_site/ - Rendered website
_scripts/doxygen_xml/ - Intermediate Doxygen XML

Never edit files in these directories manually - they will be overwritten on next build.






Update Roxygen comments in package
Rebuild docs: Rscript build_docs.R





Update Doxygen comments in headers
Rebuild docs: Rscript build_docs.R





Edit .qmd files directly
Render: quarto render or Rscript build_docs.R








Build the site:
Rscript build_docs.R full
The site is in _site/
Deploy to GitHub Pages:
# Option 1: Using gh-pages branch
git checkout --orphan gh-pages
git add _site/*
git commit -m "Deploy documentation"
git push origin gh-pages

# Option 2: Using GitHub Actions
# (see .github/workflows/deploy-docs.yml example)




The _site/ directory contains a static website that can be hosted anywhere: - Netlify: Drag and drop _site/ folder - AWS S3: Sync _site/ to bucket - Any web server: Copy _site/ contents






‚ÄúDoxygen not found‚Äù
# Install doxygen
brew install doxygen  # macOS
sudo apt-get install doxygen  # Linux
‚ÄúNo Roxygen documentation found‚Äù - Check that package path is correct in extract_roxygen.R - Verify Roxygen comments exist in R files
‚ÄúXML parsing errors‚Äù - Check Doxygen output for errors - Verify C++ header files have valid Doxygen comments
‚ÄúQuarto render fails‚Äù - Update Quarto CLI to latest version - Check .qmd file syntax - Review error messages in console




Check existing issues: https://github.com/isglobal-brge/BigDataStatMeth/issues
Quarto documentation: https://quarto.org/docs/guide/
Doxygen manual: https://www.doxygen.nl/manual/





Before each release:

Update package Roxygen documentation
Update C++ Doxygen documentation
Rebuild full documentation: Rscript build_docs.R full
Review generated API reference
Update guides/examples if needed
Test all links
Check for broken references
Build and preview site
Deploy to GitHub Pages




Same as BigDataStatMeth package.



Contributions welcome! Please:

Edit permanent content files (not generated)
Test locally before committing
Update this README if adding new features
Submit pull request


Questions? Open an issue or discussion on GitHub.

title: Installation
text:
The easiest way to install BigDataStatMeth is directly from GitHub:
# Install devtools if not already installed
if (!requireNamespace("devtools", quietly = TRUE)) {
  install.packages("devtools")
}

# Install BigDataStatMeth
devtools::install_github("isglobal-brge/BigDataStatMeth@HEAD")






R version ‚â• 4.0.0
Rtools (Windows users)
Xcode Command Line Tools (macOS users)




BigDataStatMeth depends on several R packages that will be automatically installed:

Rcpp
RcppEigen
rhdf5
DelayedArray
Other CRAN packages




For HDF5 functionality, you need the HDF5 libraries installed on your system:
Ubuntu/Debian:
sudo apt-get install libhdf5-dev
macOS (using Homebrew):
brew install hdf5
Windows: The rhdf5 package includes HDF5 libraries, so no additional installation is needed.




After installation, verify that the package loads correctly:
library(BigDataStatMeth)

# Check version
packageVersion("BigDataStatMeth")

# Run a simple test
X <- matrix(rnorm(100), ncol=10)
Y <- matrix(rnorm(100), ncol=10)
result <- bdblockmult(X, Y)

print("Installation successful!")





If you encounter compilation errors:

Make sure you have the latest version of R
Update your compiler tools (Rtools/Xcode)
Check that all system dependencies are installed




If HDF5 functions don‚Äôt work:

Verify HDF5 libraries are installed: which h5cc (Unix/macOS)
Try reinstalling the rhdf5 package
Check the HDF5 library path in your system




If problems persist:

Check existing GitHub Issues
Create a new issue with:

Your R version: sessionInfo()
Your operating system
Complete error message
Minimal reproducible example
